intro: Lupinus popayanensis, commonly known as the Popayán lupine, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of Colombia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its upright growth habit and clusters of blue to purple flowers. The plant has compound leaves with small, oval-shaped leaflets and produces cylindrical seed pods that contain several seeds. Lupinus popayanensis is adapted to high-altitude environments and plays a role in soil nitrogen fixation due to its symbiotic relationship with nitrogen-fixing bacteria.
